doc_title: 1. Yoshua Bengio: Debating AI Safety Risks
claim: Common sceptical arguments (e.g., “AIs just predict the next word”, “AIs cannot have true intelligence” or that AGI is centuries away) are misleading because what matters for x-risk is demonstrated capabilities and intentions, and empirical capability trends through 2024 make AGI/ASI plausible within uncertain but potentially short timeframes.
explanation: Mostly true. The ‘‘just predicting the next word’’ and ‘‘never true intelligence / centuries away’’ reframings are widely judged misleading because modern large models exhibit emergent reasoning, tool use and benchmark-level performance that go beyond simple memorized autocomplete (e.g., chain‑of‑thought and other reasoning results; GPT‑4’s benchmark performance). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11903?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Empirical inputs that matter for x‑risk—demonstrated capabilities, compute-and‑data trends, and actors’ stated intentions—did accelerate through 2024 (training‑compute growth and model scale rising rapidly; large expert surveys assign non‑negligible short‑to‑midterm probabilities), which makes near‑term AGI/ASI plausible within wide uncertainty bounds. ([epoch.ai](https://epoch.ai/data-insights/compute-trend-post-2010?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.02843?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) However, substantial disagreement and deep uncertainty remain (some analyses find low short‑term probabilities and many experts caution against precise dates), so the claim should not be taken as a certainty—rather as a well‑supported, evidence‑based position with important residual uncertainty. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.02519?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [cnbc.com](https://www.cnbc.com/2025/03/17/human-level-ai-will-be-here-in-5-to-10-years-deepmind-ceo-says.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
